choices.D: By default, the downstream FortiGate establishes a connection with the upstream FortiGate using TCP port 8013.
choices.B: The default port for Neighbor Discovery can be modified.
choices.C: FortiTelemetry must be manually enabled on the FortiGate interface.
choices.A: FortiTelemetry and Neighbor Discovery both operate using TCP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
the correct answer is CD

questions.question_text: Which two statements about Security Fabric communications are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Correct answer is AD.
The output only indicates that the test of the HA failover stitch failed. It doesn't confirm that an actual HA failover event occurred.

choices.A: The automation stitch test is not being logged.
choices.B: The automation stitch test failed but the HA failover was successful.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
the correct answer is D

for ECMP to work properly, both routes need to have the same priority value so the FortiGate can load-balance traffic between them. 
currently, all traffic will use port1 (due to its lower priority value of 0) and port2 will only be used if port1 fails.
by changing port1's priority to match port2's priority of 10, both default routes will have equal cost, allowing the FortiGate to implement ECMP routing to distribute web traffic across both internet connections.

choices.D: Set the priority of the static default route using port1 to 10.
choices.B: Set the priority of the static default route using port2 to 1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
The “iprope_in_check() check failed, drop” message indicates that the incoming packet failed an internal check related to routing or address translation. Two common causes are:
- Policy Route Misconfiguration (A): If a policy route is set up incorrectly (e.g., with an incorrect gateway or matching criteria), the packet might not receive the proper routing treatment and will be dropped.
- VIP or IP Pool Misconfiguration (D): When the VIP (Virtual IP) or IP pool settings are misconfigured, the FortiGate may not correctly translate or match the packet to a valid address, resulting in the drop.

choices.B: Packet was dropped because of traffic shaping.
choices.A: Packet was dropped because of policy route misconfiguration.

questions.question_text: What are two reasons you might see iprope_in_check() check failed, drop when using the debug flow? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
HA Synchronization: The session table entry shows "ha_id=0 synced". This means the session state is synchronized between the primary and secondary FortiGates. 
Failover Scenario: When the primary fails and the secondary takes over as the primary, the synchronized session state is transferred. 
Continued Traffic Flow: As long as the session state is valid and synchronized, the new primary device can continue to process traffic for this session without interruption. The client does not need to re-establish the session.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct, by default NAT sessions are not re-evaluated, therefore since it is already synced as we can see in the session state this should continue flowing normally

choices.A: The session will be removed from the session table of the secondary device because of the presence of allowed error packets, which will force the client to restart the session with the server.
choices.B: The session state is preserved but the kernel will need to re-evaluate the session because NAT was applied.
choices.D: The secondary device has this session synchronized; however, because application control is applied, the session is marked dirty and has to be re-evaluated after failover.
choices.C: Traffic for this session continues to be permitted on the new primary device after failover, without requiring the client to restart the session with the server.
